Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Situation2: They attend a local workshop on updated prescription guidelines to ensure proper patient counseling.
Story:
I glanced at the clock on my computer screen, feeling the familiar tug of anxiety. In ten minutes, our weekly team meeting would start—a routine catch-up where my presence as a colleague was expected, even though the meeting would be recorded for anyone who couldn’t make it. I knew my manager valued active participation, and I didn’t want to seem disengaged or unreliable to my teammates.

But at the same time, I had registered for a local workshop on updated prescription guidelines, scheduled to begin at the exact same time. As a pharmacist, staying current with the latest recommendations was crucial for patient safety and effective counseling. Missing this workshop meant falling behind on important changes that could impact my practice.

I stared at my calendar, feeling the pressure mount from both sides. My colleagues expected me to be present and involved, while my professional responsibility demanded I keep my knowledge sharp. The two roles pulled at me, each with their own set of expectations, and I felt caught in the middle, uncertain which obligation should take priority.
